lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: Today feels dull and plain, just like any other day.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: Not that I hate it. I’ve always expected days like this ever since I decided to open this bar.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: Still, why does it feel like my heart isn’t at peace?

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: I chose this life, and yet, deep down, I find myself yearning for something I can’t quite name.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: A man with a sharp mind and logical thinking like me, and I still can’t understand myself sometimes. How ironic.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: If she were still here, I bet she’d instantly know what I’m thinking and what I’m looking for. She always did.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: The last customer left an hour ago. So there’s no need to rush.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: People on this little street often come to my bar — not just for the drinks, but because most of them have a favor to ask.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: No matter how many times I say I don’t want to be called a detective anymore, they still trust their ‘Detective Lor’ to help.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: But seeing how happy and relieved they look afterward, the way they sincerely thank me — it does feel kinda nice.

lines.speaker: Lor
lines.text: I just can’t turn away good people trying to survive in this suffocating, chaotic city.
